BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger is within the lower range of danger level 4 (high). More natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger exists in particular in alpine snow sports terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more natural avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach quite a large size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above the tree line. Shady slopes where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches in many places. Great caution and restraint are required.

On rocky slopes numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected from the late morning. In the event of solar radiation this applies.

In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday. The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.

In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar. Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a stabilisation of the snowpack. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
In some localities up to 50 cm of snow has fallen.
The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: A lot of snow has fallen over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Natural avalanches are possible in particular on steep slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1600 m. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. In addition further individual gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. New snow is lying on a moist old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger is within the upper range of danger level 3 (considerable). More natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more natural avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach medium size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of such avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Shady slopes where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches easily. Careful route selection is recommended.

On rocky slopes numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected from the late morning. In the event of solar radiation this applies.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday. The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.

In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar. Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a stabilisation of the snowpack. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger is within the upper range of danger level 3 (considerable). More natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more natural avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach medium size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of such avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Shady slopes where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches easily. Careful route selection is recommended.

On rocky slopes numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected from the late morning. In the event of solar radiation this applies.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday. The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.

In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar. Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a stabilisation of the snowpack. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes strong northwesterly wind, wind slabs formed in particular above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.

The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease. Some medium-sized natural avalanches are, however, not entirely ruled out.
Above the tree line a dangerous avalanche situation will persist. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northwesterly wind, dangerous wind slabs formed above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.

The natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease. Individual medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are, however, not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible also at the base of rock walls.
Above the tree line and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche situation is dangerous. Experience and restraint are required.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
Weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Today the wind was moderate to strong in particular along the border with Switzerland and along the border with France.
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs formed. They are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2300 m.
As a consequence of solar radiation moist avalanches are possible in the afternoon, but they will be mostly small, in particular on very steep sunny slopes, caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Little snow fell during the night.
The northwesterly wind has transported some snow.
The snowpack is weak in some cases, in particular on shady slopes.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface on Monday, in particular on sunny slopes.
Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some snow has fallen over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Natural avalanches are possible in particular on steep slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1800 m. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. In addition gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. New snow is lying on a moist old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
As a consequence of solar radiation moist avalanches are possible in the afternoon, even medium-sized ones, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday. On very steep slopes several small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Little snow fell during the night.
The wind has transported some snow. Large wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface on Monday, in particular on sunny slopes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered, in particular on shady slopes.
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 160 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In high Alpine regions a sometimes unfavourable avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the northerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on northwest to east to southeast facing aspects and generally in high Alpine regions.
The fresh wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften quickly. Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. Also in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack above approximately 1900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.
